recipe:
Roasted Sweet Potato, Quinoa, and Tofu Bowl

This vibrant and hearty dish is perfect for a dinner party, showcasing the natural sweetness of roasted sweet potatoes, the nutty flavor of quinoa, and the satisfying texture of crispy tofu. The combination is not only visually stunning but also packed with nutrients. Feel free to swap out the quinoa for farro or brown rice, and if you prefer, you can use tempeh or chickpeas in place of tofu for a different protein option. A drizzle of tahini or a sprinkle of feta can elevate the dish even further.

### Steps
# Step 1
Preheat your oven to 425¬∞F (220¬∞C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.

# Step 2
Peel and dice 2 medium sweet potatoes into 1-inch cubes. Toss them in a bowl with 2 tablespoons of olive oil, salt, and pepper. Spread them out on the prepared baking sheet in a single layer.

# Step 3
Press 14 ounces of firm tofu to remove excess moisture, then cut it into cubes. In a separate bowl, toss the tofu with 1 tablespoon of soy sauce, 1 tablespoon of cornstarch, and a drizzle of olive oil. Add the tofu to the baking sheet with the sweet potatoes.

# Step 4
Roast the sweet potatoes and tofu in the oven for 25-30 minutes, flipping halfway through, until the sweet potatoes are tender and the tofu is golden and crispy.

# Step 5
While the sweet potatoes and tofu are roasting, rinse 1 cup of quinoa under cold water. In a medium saucepan, combine the quinoa with 2 cups of water and a pinch of salt. Bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer for 15 minutes or until the quinoa is fluffy and the water is absorbed.

# Step 6
Once everything is cooked, assemble the bowls by placing a scoop of quinoa at the bottom, topped with roasted sweet potatoes and tofu. Drizzle with tahini or your favorite dressing, and garnish with fresh herbs like cilantro or parsley.

### Tips
- For added flavor, consider marinating the tofu in a mixture of soy sauce, garlic, and ginger for at least 30 minutes before roasting.
- If you have leftover roasted sweet potatoes and quinoa, they make a fantastic base for a salad the next day. Just toss them with some greens, nuts, and a light vinaigrette for a quick lunch.
- Feel free to add seasonal vegetables like Brussels sprouts or bell peppers to the roasting pan for more variety and color.

Roasted Sweet Potatoes and Tofu with Maple Tahini Drizzle

This vibrant dish is a celebration of textures and flavors, perfect for impressing guests at your dinner party. The sweet potatoes become caramelized and tender, while the tofu crisps up beautifully, providing a satisfying contrast. The maple tahini drizzle adds a luscious, nutty sweetness that ties everything together. Feel free to swap the sweet potatoes for butternut squash or even carrots, and use any firm tofu you have on hand. This dish is not only visually stunning but also packed with nutrients, making it a wholesome centerpiece for any meal.

### Steps
# Step 1
Preheat your oven to 425¬∞F (220¬∞C). Line a large baking sheet with parchment paper.

# Step 2
Peel and cut 2 large sweet potatoes into 1-inch cubes. Drain and press 14 ounces of firm tofu to remove excess moisture, then cut it into 1-inch cubes as well.

# Step 3
In a large bowl, toss the sweet potatoes and tofu with 3 tablespoons of olive oil, 1 teaspoon of smoked paprika, 1 teaspoon of garlic powder, salt, and pepper to taste. Spread them out in a single layer on the prepared baking sheet.

# Step 4

# Step 6

# Step 7

# Step 3

# Step 5
Serve hot, garnished with sliced green onions and sesame seeds over rice or noodles.

### Tips:
- If you prefer a milder flavor, use less kimchi or rinse it briefly before adding it to the slow cooker.
